evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the early phase of the hist_pair_engine_t1 event on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains robust against alternative explanations or counter-evidence within the hist_pair_engine_t1_early context on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the incident, including timing, crew interactions, and operational context during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS with tail number 9H-QAA during the historical pair engine T1 early phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase, demonstrating robustness against defeaters.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's operational profile during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase, indicating a relevant and characteristic anomaly.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the early phase of the hist_pair_engine_t1 event on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The presence of communication and coordination described implies no significant breakdown.
The continued movement beyond TRP is attributed to procedural deviation rather than communication failure.
defeaters: If explicit evidence of miscommunication or coordination failure among crew during the early phase of hist_pair_engine_t1 emerges, or if the continued movement beyond TRP was due to communication lapses rather than procedural errors.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows coordinated communication and corrective actions by crew and tug operators, with no clear indication of communication breakdown; the behavior aligns more with procedural deviation (disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN).
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting actions as communication breakdown versus procedural deviation

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS with tail number 9H-QAA during the historical pair engine T1 early phase on 12-25.

assumptions: Ground markings (TRP) are assumed to be adequate and visible as no contrary evidence is presented.
No mechanical or communication failures contributed to the event based on available evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the ground markings were inadequate or not visible, supporting environmental deficiency instead.
If equipment faults or communication breakdowns were documented as causes.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H5 directly document the procedural deviation during pushback execution, showing the aircraft moved beyond the designated release point and hit a barrier, supporting the claim of procedural deviation rather than environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence about marker adequacy or visibility is provided, so environmental deficiency cannot be fully excluded.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's operational profile during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase, indicating a relevant and characteristic anomaly.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence.
The procedural actions and decisions by the tug instructor and trainee are representative of the procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating mechanical control failure, this would change the conclusion.
If environmental or communication factors were shown to be primary causes, the procedural deviation attribution would be weakened.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains robust against alternative explanations or counter-evidence within the hist_pair_engine_t1_early context on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

Crew communication and coordination behaviors described are representative of the overall event context.
defeaters: If evidence showed corroborated hardware faults causing the incident, or if procedural deviations fully explained the event without coordination issues, the explanation would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, with no indication of mechanical failure, supporting communication breakdown as the primary explanation over mechanical or environmental causes.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase on 12-25.

defeaters: Direct evidence of physical marking deficiency or environmental conditions affecting visibility or adequacy of markings would change the assessment.
Verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical control failure would shift support away from environmental deficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP marking and hit a barrier, indicating a possible marking or environmental issue, but no direct physical marking deficiency is confirmed; no fault codes or mechanical failures are reported, so the evidence does not discriminate clearly between environmental deficiency and mechanical control failure.
